title: Tuesday, 30th August, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Post Bank Holiday

PM

Sorry I was a tad late

11:02 am
PM

Was engrossed in the Icelandic Met Office site

PM

Icelandic Met Office, note

PM

Not the UK version, which is a fraud, since no one can predict the UK's weathher

11:03 am
PM

Icelandic Met Office rather different. Their work is rather more important, I would argue

PM

Note this:

PM

An earthquake of magnitude 3.4 was detected just north of Grindavík at 17:51 and was felt by locals.

This night on 29 August at 01:41 an earthquake swarm started within the Katla caldera. Two earthquakes were over M4. The largest earthquake occurred at 01:47:02 M4.5 and another one 20 seconds later, M4.6. The largest earthquakes were felt in the area. About 20 aftershocks have been recorded. No tremor has been seen. About 40 earthquakes have been detected within the Katla caldera from midnight. Most of them occurred before 3 AM. The largest earthquke since then had a magnitude M3.3 at 15:12.
Written by a specialist at 29 Aug 18:40 GMT

11:03 am
PM

Katla might blow

PM

One of the largest -- if not the largest volcano in Iceland

PM

11:04 am
PM

Looks like a story book volcano

PM

Here's the Icelandic Met Office btw http://en.vedur.is/#tab=skjalftar

PM

Sorry in advance for the formatting, but here's the Katla history

11:05 am
PM

Major eruptions occurred in:

1918 - VEI-4 or VEI-5; about 0.7 cubic km ejected material
1860 - VEI-4
1823 - VEI-3
1755 - VEI-5; 1.5 cubic km ejected material. Flood discharge 200,000–400,000 m³/s
1721 - VEI-5
1660 - VEI-4
1625 - VEI-5
1612 - VEI-4
1580 - VEI-4
934 - VEI-5 or VEI-6, 5 cubic km of tephra and 18 cubic km of lava

PM

Katla kinda unique in that it's an Icelandic volcano whose name we don't have to copy and past from google

PM

Unlike Eyjafjallajokull

11:06 am
PM

Snap -- commentgoeshere

PM

Patience -- i stand corrected

PM

Bit more history

11:07 am
PM

Most of these eruptions resulted in glacial floods. The severe fissure eruption in 934 was one of the largest lava eruptions in the past 10,000 years.[13] Before the Hringvegur (Iceland's Ring Road) was constructed in 1974, people feared traversing the plains in front of the volcano because of the frequent jökulhlaup (or glacier bursts) and the deep river crossings. Especially dangerous was the glacier outburst that followed the eruption of 1918.

PM

So, if Katla blows it's serious

PM

Are people selling stocks on the back of this?

11:07 am
PM

Appears not

undefined
PM

Footsie up a short 10 pionts

11:08 am
PM

But you know, it's still August

PM

Corporate news thin on the ground

PM

As you may have noticed

11:08 am
PM

And Investegate is broken for me

PM

Driven me to the LSE RNS feed, which is bloody awful

PM

Worse than the FT's even

11:09 am
PM

Just

undefined
BE

Don't get me started on the RNS theme. We can, I guess, scrape up what little there is on the tape.

11:11 am
PM

There's also bits and pieces of sell side around

PM

We'll be fine

BE

Of course. We can start with some fantasy M&A if you wish.

11:11 am
PM

Oh yeah

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 806.50, no change, High: 811.50, Low: 804.50, Volume: 357.82k
BE

"No change" ..... so .... er ..... this idea's really caught the imagination of the market.

11:12 am
PM

Maybe it just needs publicising properly

BE

The idea being that Inmarsat's cheaper in dollar terms and there are some US companies with cash that would use Inmarsat as a kind of strategic bolt-on.

BE

The logic here relies a lot on your knowledge of different spectrum types. And, knowing the rabble, they'll be 50 times more informed than us. So let's just chuck it up and let the crowd do the teardown.

11:14 am
BE

Given Inmarsat's lower share price (esp. in USD terms), rapid evolution of the industry's
competitive landscape, and historical precedents (e.g., Sky Terra approach in 2009), we
believe it is appropriate to consider potential M&A activity. In this note we assess whether
there is any rationale for Echostar, or Dish, to approach Inmarsat.

BE

Our view: Echostar (SATS) and its sister company Dish Network (DISH) have recently raised financing
and Echostar now has c.$3bn in cash on its balance sheet. This money is most likely to be used to fund new satellites at Echostar. However, there is a possibility, in our view, that Echostar or Dish may consider approaching Inmarsat given the compelling strategic and operational logic of a combination; as such, we believe this is a valid topic for investor debate.

BE

A bid for Inmarsat could help solve the jigsaw puzzle: We see a number of interlocking situations: (a) Dish has a lot of US spectrum but needs terrestrial deployment; (b) Echostar and Inmarsat both own European S band that could be used for mobile; (c) Mobile needs spectrum given data growth; (d) Deutsche Telekom is involved with Inmarsat's S-band project and owns T Mobile USA; (e) Inmarsat is global but needs needs more Ka-band; and (f) Echostar has Ka-band but wants to expand globally.

11:14 am
BE

European spectrum: Echostar and Inmarsat own the two European S band frequencies at 2GHz, with both operators launching satellites and building ground infrastructure. This spectrum is potentially very valuable if the CGC licences can be varied for terrestrial usage. Each operator has 30 MHz of panEuropean uniform spectrum adjacent to 3G, and standards body 3GPP has approved this frequency for mobile broadband in Europe and Asia. The frequencies are the same as the US AWS-4 spectrum bought by Dish for $2bn in 2011 due to a common heritage.

BE

US spectrum: We see leverage two ways: (1) Dish previously tried to buy LightSquared (now Ligado) and is keen to maximize value of its large spectrum holdings. With Ligado's business model dependent on renting capacity from Inmarsat, ownership would give Charlie Ergen (Chairman of Echostar and Dish) leverage over Ligado. (2) Deutsche Telekom is already Inmarsat's EAN partner. Ownership could allow Ergen to offer DT exclusivity in all 60 MHz of European S band in return for hosting/partnering with DT's T Mobile US business, thus solving Dish's terrestial build-out issue.

BE

RoW spectrum: Inmarsat is moving data from L-band (c.1.5 GHz) to Ka-band. We think Inmarsat, or a new owner, could in theory monetise spare capacity worldwide (as it is doing in the US), with individual governments issuing ATC/CGC style licences.
Complimentary businesses: We think combining a regional/deep operator like Echostar with a global/shallow operator like Inmarsat would fulfill Echostar's global aspirations and help Inmarsat's need to add capacity in dense areas. We also think it could protect Echostar's Hughes business, enhance in-flight opportunities, and confront ViaSat's aspirations whilst simultaneously yielding substantial operational savings from combined satellite control functions.
Financing: Despite Inmarsat's larger size ($5.0bn vs. $3.6bn) and rating (c.10x vs. 5x 2017E EBITDA), Echostar has plenty of cash ($3bn) and lower leverage. As an illustration, a 37% premium (12.5x 2017E EBITDA) with 30% cash/70% equity structure would result in NewCo leverage of 3.2x ND/ EBITDA presynergies, in line with Inmarsat's current leverage.

11:16 am
BE

There's 37 pages of this, if you want to think length gives credence to the idea.

PM

Hang on. The idea is that Echostar can bid for something 50% bigger on double the rating??

BE

Yes.

11:16 am
PM

omg smile

PM

Hallucinogenic M&S i'd say

BE

But Dish and Echostar aren't really properly listed companies. They both have B-class shares that give control to Charlie Ergen.

11:18 am
BE

I guess -- without looking into the argument any deeper -- that their quasi-private structure makes the maths above look slightly less ridiculous.

BE

Slightly

BE

In July Echostar (Nasdaq:SATS) raised $1.5bn in cash via two note issuances ($750m, Senior
Secure, 5.25%, due 2026 and $750m Senior Notes 6.625%, due 2026), taking its cash position
to $3bn. At just 0.8x 2016E Net Debt/EBITDA, Echostar appears very under-geared versus
other satellite operators. In addition, Echostar’s sister company Dish raised $2.5bn of
convertible notes in early August citing the reason for the debt issuance as “intended to be
used for strategic transactions, which may include wireless and spectrum-related strategic
transactions”.

11:19 am
BE

Would an Echostar deal be financially possible? Yes…we think so

BE

Although there appear to be compelling operational and strategic reasons for an EchostarInmarsat combination, there is the (not so) small question of relative size and rating.
As the table below shows, Inmarsat’s equity is worth c.$5bn and trades at c.10x 2017E
EBITDA, while Echostar (SATS) equity is c.30% smaller even before a bid premium, while its EV is some c.40% smaller.
However, on the flip side, Echostar has plenty of cash, with some $3bn of cash on its balance sheet post its recent debt issuance, and Inmarsat is highly levered. Since bid premia are only payable on the equity, the resulting leverage appears reasonable, in our view.

BE

11:20 am
BE

For illustration, if we assumed a multiple of 12.5x EBITDA (equating to a price of £10.89, a
30% premium) with 30% in cash / 70% equity, the resulting proforma leverage would be
3.2x – in line with Inmarsat’s current leverage of 3.3x.
A 50/50 cash/equity split at the same 12.5x multiple would result in leverage of 4.1x but
SATS shareholders would own more than 50% of the shares.

BE

BE

........... All of which looks rather like an M&A pitchbook rather than a bit of normal sellside, doesn't it?

11:21 am
PM

hmm

BE

I'm not sure what to make of it all. Perhaps it's a brilliant idea. Or perhaps it's been a long August.

PM

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our Ts&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights. http://www.ft.com/...html#ixzz4IoH1bTNU

In a white paper commissioned by Treasury secretary Jack Lew, the US touched on sensitivities over Brussels’ accountability by suggesting that the novel legal approach of the directorate leading the probe amounted to a power grab.
“This shift in approach appears to expand the role of the [competition directorate] beyond enforcement of competition and state aid law . . . into that of a supranational tax authority that reviews member state” decisions on corporate tax, it said.

BE

11:24 am

BE

11:26 am
BE

And I spent a lot of the weekend discussing the precise figures with our EU correspondent outside a pub in Brussels .... So ... er ... maybe the fast-track was overtaken somehow.

PM

Weekend in Brussels? Very nice

BE

It was, ta. Anyway, it seems to be mostly irrelevant to the investor case versus the huge excitement of Apple releasing a slightly different size of phone on September 7th.

11:28 am
BE

I'm happy to provide sellside on that .... in terms of the tax stuff, the analysts just don't give a monkeys.

BE

Here's Piper Jaffray.

BE

• What To Expect From iPhone 7. We expect the iPhone 7 to have an updated design,
although not drastically different from the iPhone 6/6S. The biggest design change is
likely the removal of the headphone jack, in favor of wireless bluetooth headphones
or headphones that use the lightning connector. Other reports suggest that the iPhone
7 Plus may have a dual lens camera, which will enable higher quality photos. Beyond
those two items, we also expect a better processor, better memory, and potentially
increasing the 16GB storage to 32GB.
• Two Shots On Goal. Our core thesis on AAPL remains that investors should own the
stock for two shots on goal over the next year. First, there is a small chance the iPhone 7
surprises positively and drives growth above levels of the iPhone 6 cycle. Second, and
more likely, in our view, the iPhone 7 is incremental as expected and the iPhone 7S/8
(10th anniversary device) is a more meaningful update with a large pool of 2-3 year old
device owners for upgrade, creating a "super-cycle." We estimate that there are around
275 million iPhones more than two years old (i.e. older than an iPhone 6) in circulation.
By comparison, we expect 234.5 million total iPhones in FY17 (iPhone 7 cycle), of which
around 150 million will be iPhone 7's.

undefined

By Amie Tsang
A woman was killed in her home and four other people were injured when a truck carrying Takata airbag parts crashed and detonated in Texas last week. The blast demonstrated just how potent the explosives used to activate Takata airbags are, creating an explosion so immense that the victim’s remains were not found for two days.

11:43 am

11:45 am

undefined
BE

So!

11:45 am
BE

Back to sellside, to fill the time.

BE

RBC has a big retail note out, which is donig the job for AB Foods.

BE

I was thinking the other day, incidentally .... AB Foods is less pure-play Primark than M&S is a pure-play grocer.

11:46 am
BE

As in, AB Foods still makes quite a lot of money from sugar and stuff.

BE

Much like M&S makes quite a lot of money from frumpy clothes. But it's mostly a posh grocer.

BE

As per the Geoff Ruddelll note we wrote up in the paper the other day.

11:47 am
BE

That's all an aside though. Here's RBC to tell you Primark's cheap.

BE

Our view: ABF shares are down 12% ytd but our FY17/18 EPS forecasts
are +6% higher than at the start of the year. We think ABF has a healthy
double-digit EPS CAGR with EPS momentum owing to Primark share gains
and recent strength in Sugar and Euro prices. Our survey work favours
Primark which still offers an attractive international rollout story. Upgrade
to Outperform and raise our PT to GBp3,400 from GBp2,800.

BE

Survey work favours Primark. We think Primark is relatively well
positioned as it is the cheapest retailer in the price-conscious UK apparel
sector. It has also improved on customer perception for product and style
according to our latest customer survey. In addition it has relatively high
non-UK exposure (c.50% of Primark and c.57% of group sales) meaning it is
relatively shielded from cost and currency pressures in the UK. We expect
LFL sales to remain muted owing to a tough consumer backdrop and the
lack of an ecommerce offer, however we have raised them slightly versus
easy comparisons from FY16E.

11:49 am
BE

(@Roddy: surely any politician arguing that is -- in the most literal sense -- writing a cheque they can't cash.)

BE

Primark taking share in fragmented clothing markets - Our store potential
analysis suggests Primark has potential to add at least a high single digit
rate of store growth over the next ten years in existing markets.
Italy off to a strong start - in the large, fragmented, fashion forward Italian
clothing market Primark appears to have made a good start particularly in
womens and kidswear. We think menswear has more scope to improve,
due to quality expectations and as mens' sportswear needs to be more
differentiated. We think Italy is a higher cost to serve market than Spain
but lower than France and so it should be one of the group's higher margin
markets in time.
Sugar seeing a dramatic recovery - for Sugar a reduction in EU stock
levels and a recent increase in world sugar prices have resulted in a
strengthening in European sugar prices. This should help AB Sugar's profit
trajectory from next year. We also think an exit from China would be well
received by the market and would further strengthen ABF's already underleveraged
balance sheet.
Valuation reasonable given attractive EPS CAGR - today we have raised
our EPS forecasts by 4-6% owing to a stronger outlook for Sugar, higher
confidence in Primark and a more helpful currency picture for Sugar,
Primark and Grocery. ABF is trading on a CY17E P/E of 24x which implies
a P/E of Primark of 26x. This is just below Inditex which we think is
reasonable given Primark's earlier stage international rollout story but
lack of an ecommerce offer. Overall ABF offers amongst the best earnings
growth in the sector with a projected 16% EPS growth for FY17 and a 3
year estimated EPS CAGR of 12%.

BE

That's all part of a bigger retail sector piece, arguing that it's pretty moribund but okay if you have a decent website.

11:50 am
BE

UK consumer headwinds - we estimate UK consumers will see a flatter trend in disposable income in 2017 compared to c.+5% this year, owing to a likely weaker labour market and higher inflation. This, along with our expectation of a small fall in housing transactions, is causing downwards pressure on our main lead indicator for UK retail sales.

BE

Consumer survey work suggests Inditex US and H&M China opportunities - we see an opportunity for Inditex to accelerate its growth in the US as more prime real estate becomes available and as its online offer appears to be gaining traction, with particular strength in delivery and payment options. Our survey also suggests the H&M brand is very highly regarded in China despite recent sales weakness there, which suggests a likely sales improvement as H&M adapts its offer and improves its execution in tier 3 and 4 cities there.

BE

Pricing surveys show shifts in midmarket pricing - our UK apparel entry point pricing survey suggests both M&S and Next have become relatively more price competitive compared to Debenhams. Zara’s pricing appears to be more stable to up this season following the last two years when it has cut prices in the UK to be closer to those in Germany.

11:51 am
BE

........... So ...............

BE

Lower Debenhams to Sector Perform - we downgrade Debenhams as we see higher than average risk to LFL sales given higher dollar sourcing costs and more price competition in the UK midmarket.

Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 60.90, down 1.9 (-3.03%), High: 62.40, Low: 60.60, Volume: 1.19m
11:51 am

Braemar off 10% now

11:54 am
PM

PM

http://www.investe...1608300700122991I/

PM

Braemar is well financed with a strong balance sheet and substantial forward order book. We remain confident in and committed to our long term strategy of organic and acquisitive investment together with diversification and expansion in our core markets. However, while the results for the year ending 28 February 2017 will be materially lower than 2016, the structural management changes and cost reduction measures we have put in place (the costs of which will substantially fall in the first half of the current year) will result in an improvement in business performance.

11:55 am
BE

Both sides of the market poor. Tankers and dry cargo.

BE

Straight readthrough for Inmarsat, incidentally, given shipping's quite a lot of its revenue.

BE

But Inmarsat's not moving either direction, which makes both the fantasy M&A line and the earnings readthrough line rather forced by necessity.

11:56 am
BE

Have Cantor on Braemar. They downgrade.

BE

Profit warning – BMS has issued a profit warning. Tanker markets have seen lower activity levels and freight rates which has led to reduced revenues. In the dry cargo markets, the company states that despite healthy demand and good transaction volumes, overcapacity continues to depress freight rates to historically low levels. Cost cutting measures have been put in place to reduce costs in this area. BMS’s vessel sale & purchase and offshore desks continue to perform in line with management expectations, with similar levels of activity to the previous year. Generally, USD denominated earnings in these divisions will benefit from the weakness of GBP if the exchange rate is sustained at current levels. In the Technical services division, the slowdown in oil & gas exploration and new project work continues to impact surveying and engineering businesses, particularly in relation to offshore activity. To respond to these tough market conditions, the company has already made a number of senior management changes in the Technical division. The Logistics division continues to perform in line with management expectations. As a result of these events, earnings for the year ending 28 February 2017 for the group will be “materially” lower than for 2016. BMS further states that it is “well financed” with a strong balance sheet and “substantial” order book, cost cutting measures and new divisional management should lead to an improvement in underlying performance. We cut our forecasts for underlying operating profit for FY17 by over 30% to £9m and our EPS is cut by 24% to 23p. Cuts are made to divisional profits in Shipbroking and Technical. Our FY18 and FY19 forecasts are placed under review. Our recommendation is changed to HOLD from BUY, our TP is placed under review. Interim results will be released on Tuesday 25 October, 2016.

BE

Risks and target price – Demand for global maritime shipbroking and technical services, acquisition execution and currency fluctuation. Our TP is derived using a 10 year DCF of net cash, this is placed under review from 520p.

11:57 am
Braemar Shipping Services PLC (BMS:LSE): Last: 369.00, down 37 (-9.11%), High: 395.75, Low: 362.00, Volume: 110.20k

Adds that control is now passing to a "very heavily-indebted, very unfocused business in Japan which does not have a good record of buying foreign companies and continuing to invest in them.

12:07 pm

BE

PM
